title: 107_hr5241
content: The Act titled "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2002" amends the Public Health Service Act by adding a new section on Lifespan Respite Care. This section includes findings and purposes related to respite care. Congress finds that approximately 26 million individuals in the US care for adult family members or friends who are chronically ill, disabled, or terminally ill. Additionally, around 18 million children have conditions requiring caregiver supervision, and about 6 million children live with relatives due to parental inability or unwillingness to care for them. Approximately 6,000,000 children in the United States live with a grandparent or other relative because their parents are unable or unwilling to care for them. An estimated 165,000 children with disabilities live with a foster care parent, and nearly 4,000,000 individuals of all ages with mental retardation or developmental disabilities live with their families. Additionally, almost 25 percent of the Nation's elders experience multiple chronic disabling conditions. Approximately 600,000 Americans die at home each year, relying on extensive family caregiving before their deaths. 42 percent of individuals in the United States needing daily living assistance are under age 65, and there are insufficient resources to replace family caregivers with paid workers. Approximately 75 percent of family caregivers are women, and the family caregiver role can result in emotional, physical, and financial hardship. If family caregivers had to be replaced with paid services, it would cost around $200 billion annually. Approximately 75 percent of family caregivers are women, facing emotional, physical, and financial hardship. They often struggle to find information on respite care, which is insufficient and mainly targets lower-income populations and elderly caregivers, leaving many without adequate support. The available respite care programs are inadequate, primarily serving lower-income and elderly caregivers, leaving many without support. There is a shortage of trained respite workers, prompting the need for State and local lifespan respite care programs. The purposes of this title are to encourage States to establish respite care programs, improve information dissemination to family caregivers, provide respite care services, and promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery and worker training. The purposes of this title are to encourage States to establish respite care programs, improve information dissemination to family caregivers, provide respite care services, promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery, support evaluative research on effective respite care services, and disseminate research findings. The purpose of this section is to support evaluative research on effective respite care services and promote the dissemination of results and findings related to respite care delivery and family caregiver training. "SEC. 2802. DEFINITIONS." The term 'condition' in this title includes Alzheimer's disease, developmental disabilities, mental retardation, physical disabilities, chronic illness (such as cancer), behavioral and emotional conditions, cognitive impairments, and situations with a high risk of abuse or neglect. The term 'condition' includes cognitive impairments, high-risk situations for abuse or neglect, parental unavailability due to death or incapacity, traumatic brain injury, and other conditions designated by the Secretary. Eligible recipients are State agencies. The term 'eligible recipient' includes State agencies, public entities operating statewide, nonprofit organizations operating statewide, political subdivisions with a population of at least 3,000,000 individuals, and recognized State respite coordinating entities. Eligible recipients include State agencies, public entities, nonprofit organizations, political subdivisions with a population of at least 3,000,000 individuals, and recognized State respite coordinating agencies with demonstrated abilities in respite care and family caregiver issues. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a family caregiver as an unpaid individual providing care for a child or adult with special needs. It also defines lifespan respite care as a coordinated system of accessible, community-based care. The curr_chunk defines lifespan respite care as a system of community-based services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs, providing temporary relief to the caregiver. The term 'respite care' refers to planned or emergency care for individuals with special needs to provide temporary relief to family caregivers or when the caregiver is unable to provide care. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. 'Special need' pertains to the specific care requirements of individuals of any age due to a condition. The term 'special need' refers to the particular needs of individuals of any age who require care or supervision due to a condition in order to meet their basic needs or prevent harm to them. "SEC. 2803. LIFESPAN RESPITE CARE GRANTS AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS." The section aims to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible recipients for this purpose. The Secretary may award grants to eligible recipients for expanding respite care services and reducing family caregiver strain. Coordination with various agencies is required for a Federal Lifespan Approach. The National Family Caregiver Support Program, in coordination with multiple agencies, ensures respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Eligible recipients must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant or cooperative agreement. Applicants seeking a grant or cooperative agreement must submit an application to the Secretary with required information, including understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues, capacity for family involvement, and care recipient support. The application must include an understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues, capacity for family involvement, and collaboration with other agencies. It should also describe the population of family caregivers who will receive respite care information or services. The application must include a description of the population for whom respite care information or services will be provided, including the extent and nature of their respite care needs, existing services, and methods/systems in place. The curr_chunk focuses on the population served, unmet needs, coordination of respite care information and services at State and local levels, recruitment and training programs for respite care workers and volunteers. The curr_chunk outlines plans for respite care information dissemination, coordination, services, worker/volunteer recruitment, and training programs using grant funds. Collaboration and coordination of respite care are also included in the plan. The curr_chunk focuses on the plan for respite care services using grant funds, including collaboration with other related services and programs offered by public or private entities. The curr_chunk outlines how the population and relevant agencies will participate in planning respite care activities and how other funds and resources will be utilized. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of utilizing various federal, state, and local resources, programs, and facilities to improve respite care services for family caregivers in the applicant's State or locality. The curr_chunk focuses on improving the coordination and distribution of respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. It includes criteria for identifying eligible caregivers and monitoring the quality and safety of respite care services provided. The curr_chunk outlines monitoring methods for respite care services, ensuring workers possess necessary skills, and expected results from activities. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of a review panel to evaluate applications for respite care services, including the expected results from activities and confidentiality assurances for care recipient and family caregiver records. The Secretary will establish a panel to review applications for respite care services, ensuring confidentiality of care recipient and family caregiver records. The panel will meet as needed to evaluate applications and make recommendations for approval. The panel will review and evaluate applications for respite care services, making recommendations to the Secretary for approval. The Secretary will award grants or cooperative agreements based on the panel's recommendations, prioritizing applicants with the greatest likelihood of success. When awarding grants, the Secretary prioritizes applicants likely to implement or enhance lifespan respite care statewide. Grant funds must be used for developing respite care at State and local levels. The cooperative agreement requires the recipient to use funds for developing lifespan respite care, providing respite care services, and evaluating effectiveness. Subcontracts are also required for eligible recipients. The cooperative agreement mandates the use of funds for developing lifespan respite care, providing services, and evaluating effectiveness. Recipients can subcontract with public or nonprofit agencies for these activities. Grants or cooperative agreements awarded under this section have a maximum term of 5 years. The Secretary can award grants or cooperative agreements for up to 5 years and may renew them. Funds must supplement, not replace, other available funds for respite care services. The Secretary will award a grant to establish a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care. The Center will maintain a national database, provide training and assistance to respite care programs, and offer information and educational programs to the public. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the establishment of a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care.
